(4) The scope of this law shall not be extended a) * XXXXVII from 2009 on forests, forest protection and forest management. for the establishment, protection, use, encroachment into the interior of the forest and forest management in accordance with the law (hereinafter: Evt.); b) to protect the earth as an element of the environment. (4a) * The Forestry Administration has the right to determine and confirm which area is classified as forest as defined in Evt. (5) The provisions of this law shall apply to agricultural land under nature protection - unless otherwise determined by the law on nature protection. (6) The provisions of this law are applied together with the land protection regulations of other laws. (7) * The rules for agricultural land must be applied to real estate registered in the real estate register as an enclosed garden (hereinafter: enclosed garden property) if the enclosed garden property - based on the data in the real estate register - meets the requirements of the definition of agricultural land defined by this law.

title: OREGON EASTSIDE FORESTS RESTORATION, OLD GROWTH PROTECTION, AND JOBS
rows: OREGON EASTSIDE FORESTS RESTORATION, OLD GROWTH PROTECTION, AND JOBS

The "Oregon Eastside Forests Restoration, Old Growth Protection, and Jobs Act of 2013" aims to restore forest landscapes, protect old growth forests, and manage national forests in Oregon's eastside forests. It emphasizes conservation, collaboration among stakeholders, and scientific expertise. The legislation includes provisions for vegetation management projects, retention of older trees, limitations on road construction, and monitoring for effective management. Its goal is to promote ecosystem restoration and involve stakeholders in decision-making processes.

title: Wildlife Corridors Conservation Act of 2016
rows: The "Wildlife Corridors Conservation Act of 2016" establishes a National Wildlife Corridors System to conserve and restore habitats for native species. It requires government departments to designate and manage corridors, promotes species connectivity, and ensures safety on roads. Land acquisition is allowed using designated funds, and a database for native species habitats is created. The Wildlife Corridors Stewardship and Protection Fund supports corridor management and protection.

title: Protecting America's Wilderness and Public Lands Act
rows: Protecting America's Wilderness and Public Lands Act

The Protecting America's Wilderness and Public Lands Act aims to preserve and conserve public lands while promoting recreational use. It designates wilderness areas, trails, and scenic rivers in various states, establishes special management areas, and expands national parks. The bill also includes provisions for coal mine methane use, heritage areas, and grants for outdoor recreation.

title: ESTUARY HABITAT RESTORATION PARTNERSHIP ACT OF 1998
rows: ESTUARY HABITAT RESTORATION PARTNERSHIP ACT OF 1998

The Committee on Environment and Public Works has reported favorably on the bill (S. 1222) aimed at restoring estuary habitat through better financing and coordination of restoration programs. Estuaries are important ecosystems that support diverse wildlife and have significant economic value. The bill establishes a program to restore one million acres of estuary habitat by 2010 and includes measures to protect and restore specific estuaries like the Chesapeake Bay and Long Island Sound. It also addresses the control of Pfiesteria piscicida, a harmful microbe. The bill expands the authority of the National Estuary Program and provides grants for estuary restoration projects.

title: Loi n 2007-03 portant rgime foncier rural en Rpublique du Bnin
rows: Loi n 2007-03 portant rgime foncier rural en Rpublique du Bnin
La loi concerne le rgime foncier rural au Bnin, englobant les terres agricoles, les ressources naturelles et les activits conomiques dans les zones rurales.

title: Programme dAction Nationale de Lutte contre la Dsertification (PAN/LCD)
rows: Programme dAction Nationale de Lutte contre la Dsertification (PAN/LCD)

The PAN/LCD is a national action plan for the fight against desertification in Chad. It was adopted in 2006 and aims to contribute to the sustainable management of land resources in the country. The plan has four main objectives: Protect, restore, and enhance the productive potential of land resources;Protect and conserve threatened and important ecosystems;Strengthen national capacity to combat desertification; andManage the risks associated with desertification. Specific measures to promote land restoration, such as: Promoting the use of sustainable agricultural practices; Restocking degraded grazing lands; Planting trees and shrubs; Rehabilitating water bodies; and Reducing the impact of human activities on the environment.

title: Kigali Declaration
rows: The Kigali Declaration serves as a framework for promoting environmental conservation, sustainable development, and green growth in Africa. It aligns with regional and global initiatives, such as the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the African Union's Agenda 2063. The declaration highlights the importance of sustainable land management practices, including reforestation, soil conservation, and sustainable agriculture, to address land degradation and promote ecosystem restoration on the continent. Sustainable Land Management: The Kigali Declaration recognizes the importance of sustainable land management practices. It emphasizes the need to address land degradation and desertification, which are key issues that necessitate land restoration actions. Ecosystem Conservation: The declaration emphasizes the conservation and sustainable use of ecosystems, including forests, wetlands, and other natural habitats. Preserving and restoring these ecosystems are crucial components of land restoration efforts. Climate Change Adaptation and Mitigation: The Kigali Declaration acknowledges the impact of climate change on ecosystems and the need to adapt to its effects. Land restoration can play a vital role in climate change adaptation and mitigation, such as through reforestation and the enhancement of carbon sequestration in restored landscapes. Green Growth and Sustainable Development: The declaration promotes green growth as a pathway to sustainable development. Land restoration contributes to green growth by improving land productivity, enhancing ecosystem services, and supporting livelihoods in a sustainable manner. Collaboration and Cooperation: The Kigali Declaration calls for increased collaboration and cooperation among African countries and international partners. This collaborative approach is essential for sharing knowledge, resources, and best practices in land restoration and fostering collective action towards achieving restoration goals.

title: National Strategy for Combating Desertification, Land Degradation, and Drought
rows: National Strategy for Combating Desertification, Land Degradation, and Drought

The National Strategy for Combating Desertification, Land Degradation, and Drought (NSCDDLD) was adopted by the Government of Sudan in 2006. It is a comprehensive plan that aims to address the challenges of desertification, land degradation, and drought in the country. The NSCDDLD has four main objectives: To protect and restore degraded land resources; To promote sustainable land management practices; To reduce the vulnerability of people to the effects of desertification, land degradation, and drought; and To build national capacity to combat desertification. The NSCDDLD includes a number of specific measures to promote land restoration, such as: Promoting the use of rainwater harvesting techniques; Restocking degraded grazing lands; Planting trees and shrubs; Rehabilitating water bodies; and Reducing the impact of human activities on the environment.

title: Environmental Code of Mauritania
rows: The Environmental Code of Mauritania serves as a comprehensive legal framework for environmental protection and sustainable development in the country. While it may not specifically focus on land restoration, it includes provisions related to the conservation, management, and rehabilitation of ecosystems, which indirectly contribute to land restoration efforts. Law no. 2000-045 (on the Environmental Code) is the main piece of environmental legislation in Mauritania. The code defines the rights and responsibilities of individuals and organizations with respect to the environment, and establishes a number of institutions and procedures for environmental protection. The code has a number of provisions that are relevant to land and ecosystem restoration. For example, it prohibits the clearing of vegetation without authorization, and requires that all projects that are likely to have a significant impact on the environment undergo an environmental impact assessment. The code also establishes a number of protected areas, including national parks, nature reserves, and biosphere reserves.

target_key: Morocco (also applied partly to West Sahara)
title: LOI-CADRE N 99-12 PORTANT CHARTE NATIONALE DE LENVIRONNEMENT ET DU DEVELOPPEMENT DURABLE
rows: LOI-CADRE N 99-12 PORTANT CHARTE NATIONALE DE LENVIRONNEMENT ET DU DEVELOPPEMENT DURABLE
Morocco (also applied partly to West Sahara)

The National Charter for the Environment and Sustainable Development serves as a comprehensive policy document that guides environmental protection and sustainable development initiatives in Morocco. The charter emphasizes the principles of sustainable development, including the integration of environmental considerations in various sectors, the protection of natural resources, and the promotion of sustainable land use practices.  Promote the use of sustainable and efficient water resource management practices, combat water pollution, and update water legislation to adapt it to the requirements of sustainable development and the combined effects of desertification and climate change.  Ensure the ecological balance of forests, forest ecosystems, and biodiversity, including the conservation of endemic, rare, threatened, or endangered animal and plant species, through the updating of existing legislation.  Establish a specific legal framework to protect soil from all forms of degradation and pollution and allocate land use based on its purpose.  Strengthen resources allocated to combating desertification and preserving biodiversity, particularly in oasis and steppe areas.  Promote the protection of marine and coastal ecosystems, as well as wetlands, against the impacts of activities that may alter or deplete water and resources.  Preserve and enhance mountain ecosystems, safeguarding their resources and environmental quality against any form of degradation.  Preserve and enhance terrestrial, coastal, and marine sites of biological and ecological interest, encouraging the creation of protected areas.  Preserve, enhance, and restore tangible and intangible elements of historical and cultural heritage.

title: National Strategy for Biodiversity and the National Plan for Ecological Continuity
rows: National Strategy for Biodiversity and the National Plan for Ecological Continuity

France has implemented various legislation and policies aimed at land restoration and ecological conservation. The National Strategy for Biodiversity and the National Plan for Ecological Continuity are two key initiatives in this regard. The National Strategy for Biodiversity sets out the objectives and actions to protect and restore biodiversity in France. It includes measures related to habitat restoration, reforestation, sustainable land management, and the preservation of ecosystems. The strategy emphasizes the importance of maintaining and restoring ecological connectivity between different natural areas. The National Plan for Ecological Continuity focuses on the preservation and restoration of ecological corridors to facilitate the movement of species and maintain biodiversity. It aims to ensure the connectivity of ecosystems, including through measures such as habitat restoration, wildlife corridors, and ecological infrastructure planning.

title: Environment and Development Planning Act (Chapter 504)
rows: The Environment and Development Planning Act (Chapter 504) is the primary legislation in Malta that addresses environmental protection and sustainable development. While the Act does not specifically focus on land restoration, it includes provisions related to the conservation, management, and rehabilitation of ecosystems, which indirectly contribute to land restoration efforts. The Act establishes the legal framework for the protection and management of the environment, including the conservation and restoration of ecosystems. It promotes sustainable land use practices, regulates development activities to minimize environmental impacts, and ensures the integration of environmental considerations in planning and decision-making processes.

title: Loi n 84-12 du 23 juin 1984 portant rgime gnral des forts.
rows: Loi n 84-12 du 23 juin 1984 portant rgime gnral des forts.

While this law primarily focuses on forests, it includes provisions related to land restoration and rehabilitation. Forest Rehabilitation and Restoration: The law promotes the rehabilitation and restoration of forest ecosystems, which can contribute to the restoration of land as well. It emphasizes the importance of preserving the ecological balance of forests and implementing measures for the rehabilitation of degraded forest areas. Afforestation and Reforestation: The law encourages afforestation and reforestation activities, which involve planting trees on degraded lands or areas previously affected by deforestation. These activities contribute to the restoration of vegetation cover and the improvement of soil conditions. Soil Protection: The law includes provisions for the protection of forest soils from degradation, erosion, and other forms of damage. By safeguarding the integrity of forest soils, the law indirectly contributes to land restoration efforts. Sustainable Forest Management: The law promotes sustainable forest management practices, which encompass the conservation and restoration of forest ecosystems. Sustainable forest management aims to maintain or enhance the productive functions of forests while ensuring the long-term ecological, economic, and social benefits. In order to protect lands against erosion or desertification, areas of public utility for the protection, restoration, and enhancement of designated zones can be created by decree.

title: Sustainable Agricultural Development Strategy towards 2030
rows: The Sustainable Agricultural Development Strategy towards 2030 in Egypt aims to modernize agriculture, achieve food security, and improve the livelihoods of rural inhabitants while utilizing environmental advantages. Key points related to land restoration and degradation in the strategy include: Sustainable use of natural agricultural resources: The strategy promotes the sustainable use of agricultural resources, emphasizing the protection and restoration of agricultural land, and the efficient utilization of water resources. Maximizing sustainable productivity: The strategy focuses on maximizing the sustainable productivity of land and water units. This involves improving water-use efficiency, expanding reclaimed areas, implementing water harvesting techniques for rainfed agriculture, and maintaining and protecting agricultural land. Reduction of agricultural land degradation: The strategy emphasizes the need to address agricultural land degradation. This includes conducting soil surveys, implementing measures for continued restoration and maintenance of the drainage system, and combating desertification to protect agricultural land, rangelands, and biological diversity. Job creation and poverty reduction: The strategy aims to improve the livelihoods of rural populations and reduce rural poverty. It seeks to create job opportunities in agriculture and related activities and encourages the participation of farmers, especially small farmers and rural women, in agricultural development initiatives. Monitoring and evaluation: The strategy proposes establishing transparent mechanisms for monitoring and evaluating extension activities, including the participation of researchers and farmers. It also suggests the establishment of a national network for monitoring climate and environmental variables to address natural disasters and risks to agriculture.

title: Law No.5 of 1982 on the protection of grasslands and forests.
rows: Law No.5 of 1982 on the protection of grasslands and forests.

Soil stabilization and prevention of degradation and desertification: The law emphasizes the importance of developing the vegetative cover and afforestation as measures to stabilize the soil, prevent land degradation, and combat desertification. Prohibition of cutting certain trees or plants: The legislation prohibits the cutting of specific types of trees or plants to protect them from depletion and ensure their contribution to land restoration efforts. Restoration of public forests and grasslands: The General People's Committee for Agricultural Land Reclamation and Reconstruction, as the responsible authority, is tasked with implementing measures to restore and manage public forests and grasslands. This includes taking actions to rehabilitate degraded areas, promote the growth of vegetation, and enhance the overall ecological health of these lands. Prevention of harmful activities: The law prohibits activities that could negatively impact land restoration efforts, such as cultivating the soil, building or fencing, altering watercourses, and using toxic substances or inflammable materials. These provisions highlight the commitment of the Libyan government to address land degradation, promote land restoration, and protect the environment for sustainable development. By focusing on soil stabilization, afforestation, and the restoration of degraded lands, the legislation aims to safeguard the long-term productivity and ecological integrity of Libya's land resources.

title: Loi n95-70, du 17 juillet 1995, relative  la conservation des eaux et du sol, telle que modifie par la loi n2004-24 du 15 mars 2004.
rows: Loi n95-70, du 17 juillet 1995, relative  la conservation des eaux et du sol, telle que modifie par la loi n2004-24 du 15 mars 2004.

This law aims to address land degradation and promote land restoration through various measures. It focuses on the conservation of areas threatened by water erosion, wind erosion, and sand encroachment. The law establishes the implementation of water and soil conservation works within intervention perimeters based on development plans. It emphasizes the importance of preventing erosion and degradation of agricultural land, siltation of reservoirs, and risks to infrastructure and urban areas caused by flooding and landslides. The law includes provisions for the proper management of agricultural activities to prevent obstruction of natural water flow. It regulates the use of specific tools and techniques in designated areas and prohibits grazing and exploitation of certain plantations and watercourses. Landowners and agricultural operators are required to cooperate with the execution of conservation works and allow the activities of competent agents responsible for implementing and monitoring development plans. In case of total deprivation of land use, they are entitled to compensation. The law also establishes organizations at the national, regional, and local levels to oversee water and soil conservation efforts. These organizations, along with landowners and agricultural operators, can receive state support and encouragement for the development and expansion of water and soil conservation works. The law concludes with a section outlining the penalties for violations of its provisions, highlighting the importance of compliance with the law's regulations.

title: Guide Forts Durables
rows: The text highlights several strategies and measures aimed at addressing land degradation and promoting land restoration in Tunisia. These include: Reforestation and Forest Management: The Sustainable Forests Guide emphasizes the importance of improving forest cover through reforestation and effective forest management practices. These actions help combat land degradation and erosion, protecting the soil from water and wind erosion. Sand Fixation and Desertification Control: Tunisia recognizes the need to combat desertification through sand fixation measures. By implementing techniques to stabilize and fix sand dunes, the country aims to prevent further land degradation and the encroachment of desert areas. Fire Prevention and Control: The plan acknowledges the threat of wildfires and emphasizes the importance of fire prevention and control measures. Vigilance systems, alert mechanisms, and rapid response resources are employed to mitigate the impact of fires on land degradation. Sustainable Pastoral Management: The strategies emphasize the improvement and sustainable management of rangelands. By implementing appropriate grazing practices and pastoral management techniques, the aim is to reduce overgrazing, which can contribute to land degradation, and enhance the productivity and resilience of rangeland ecosystems. Biodiversity Conservation and Protected Areas: The plan recognizes the importance of conserving flora and fauna, as well as protecting natural habitats and biodiversity. By establishing and managing protected areas, Tunisia aims to preserve ecosystems, regenerate plant and animal species, and safeguard against further land degradation. Socio-economic Development and Livelihood Improvement: The strategies also focus on socio-economic aspects related to land degradation and restoration. This includes the utilization of forest resources for various purposes, such as timber, forage, honey, and game, which can improve the livelihoods of local communities dependent on these resources.

title: Plan Forestier National NIGER (2012-2021)
rows: Conservation of Forests: The plan focuses on safeguarding and securing classified forests, parks, and reserves. This measure helps protect these areas from degradation and ensures their long-term conservation. Soil Conservation and Erosion Control: The plan includes actions to conserve soils and combat erosion. This involves the restoration of degraded lands, combating sand encroachment, seeding herbaceous plants to restore vegetation cover, and controlling invasive plant species. Sustainable Use of Productive Resources: The plan promotes the sustainable management and development of productive resources. This approach ensures that the use of forest resources is carried out in a manner that minimizes degradation and allows for their long-term availability. Biodiversity Preservation: The plan emphasizes the preservation and valorization of biodiversity in natural environments. This includes measures to protect and restore habitats, conserve endangered species, and maintain ecosystem balance. Research and Adaptation to Climate Change: The plan emphasizes the need for forest research focused on understanding the impacts of forestry on resilience and climate change. This knowledge helps inform strategies for land restoration and adaptation to changing climatic conditions. Restoration of Degraded Lands: The plan includes efforts to restore degraded lands by implementing measures such as reforestation and afforestation. These actions help increase vegetation cover, enhance soil quality, and combat land degradation. Participation and Capacity Building: The plan recognizes the importance of mobilizing and involving various stakeholders, including rural communities, public institutions, development partners, and private operators. Capacity building initiatives aim to enhance knowledge and skills for sustainable land management.

title: Plan National Scheresse du Mali 2021-2025.
rows: Primarily focuses on drought management and resilience rather than directly addressing land degradation and restoration. However, some elements indirectly relate to land degradation and restoration efforts. Here are the relevant points: The National Drought Plan aims to reduce the vulnerability of the country to drought and its impacts, which can include land degradation. By implementing measures to respond to drought and limit its impacts, such as soil erosion and desertification, the plan indirectly contributes to mitigating land degradation. The plan emphasizes the need to assess vulnerability and risks related to drought, which can include assessing the impact of drought on land resources and identifying areas prone to degradation. This assessment can inform targeted interventions for land restoration and sustainable land management. The plan highlights the importance of sustainable natural resource management, which includes the management of land resources. By creating a conducive environment for sustainable resource management, the plan indirectly supports efforts to address land degradation.

title: The Presidential Decrees On measures to improve the effectiveness of efforts to combat desertification and drought in the Republic of Uzbekistan
rows: The Presidential Decrees On measures to improve the effectiveness of efforts to combat desertification and drought in the Republic of Uzbekistan
It is about improving the efficiency of country activities of reducing the desertification, recovery of degraded lands and implementing Uzbekistan's international commitments

title: RESOLUTION OF THE PRESIDENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF UZBEKISTAN ON MEASURES TO CREATE AN EFFECTIVE SYSTEM TO COMBAT LAND DEGRADATION
rows: RESOLUTION OF THE PRESIDENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF UZBEKISTAN ON MEASURES TO CREATE AN EFFECTIVE SYSTEM TO COMBAT LAND DEGRADATION

In order to combat land degradation in Uzbekistan and mitigate its negative consequences, prevent desertification and drought in the regions, preserve biodiversity, preserve and improve soil fertility, restore degraded lands, achieve sustainable development of regions based on the widespread use of advanced scientific developments and innovations in this area

title: Law on Pastures
rows: It defines the legal, economic and organizational framework sustainable pasture management and regulates relations related to the use and protection pastures, increasing their ecological, economic and resource potential.

title: Me v yallq zonalar, mlumatlar, v mhafizsi bard monitorinqin nticlri bard icmal
rows: Me v yallq zonalar, mlumatlar, v mhafizsi bard monitorinqin nticlri bard icmal

Bu mlumatn hazrlanmasnda sas mqsd Azrbaycanda bu sah il mul olan mtxssislrd lknin me v yallq sahlri bard mvcud vziyyt bard icmal mlumatn atdrlmasdr. Bildiyimiz kimi me v yallq sahlri, tbit estetik gzllikdn baqa btn canllarn hyatnn davam etmsi n zruri olan oksigenl tmin edir. Bel ki, agaclar v yallqlar atmosferd olan karbon qazn(CO2) udaraq vzind btn kainat oksigenl tmin edir. Nvndn v yandan asl olaraq bir aac bir il rzind hesablamalar gr 100 kq oksigen istehsal edrk 35-40 kq karbon qazn udur. Bir insann il rzind 740-760 kq oksigen istifad etdiyi nzr alnsa 7-8 aacn bir insann udaca qdr oksigen istehsal etdiyini myyn edil bilr. Yallq razilri az olan yerlrd oksigen atmazl olduundan mxtlif xstliklrin artmas mahid olunur. Xsusil Bak hrind v digr hrlrimizd yallq sahlri dnya zr mumi orta normadan aa olduundan hrd oksigen atmazl mahid olunur. title: Nepal Land Use Policy 2015
rows: The primary goal of the legislation is the sustainable management of land. However, its genuine The policy provision comprises a land use zoning which has 11 categories of land use such as agricultural zone, residential zone, commercial zone, industrial zone, mineral zone, cultural and archaeological zone, river, lake, and pond zone, public use and open zone, construction material extraction zone, and other zones designated as per need. Other policy provisions emphasize: (i) formulation of federal, provincial, and local level land use plans and their implementation; (ii) preparation and implementation of physical infrastructural development projects in consonance with governance level-specific land use plan, and (iii) ensuring the optimum use of agricultural land and its conservation by discouraging the use of agricultural land for the non-agricultural purpose, the culture of keeping the agricultural land fallow, and uncontrolled fragmentation of such agricultural land.

title: National Agro-Forestry Policy, 2019
rows: The vision of the policy is to contribute to national prosperity through the development, extension, and commercialization of agro-forestry system. Its objectives comprise as follows: (i) to augment the production of agriculture, livestock, and forest-related products by enhancing the productivity of land and using it multi-purposely; (ii) to reduce population pressure on land and conserve environmental and biological biodiversity, maintain soil quality and develop climate friendly environmental system; (iii) to ensure food security of local communities by creating opportunities for livelihood, employment and income generation through the intensive promotion of agroforestry; (iv) to contribute to the economy through commercialization by creating investment opportunities in agro-forestry, and (v) to promote the study, research and capacity in agro-forestry subject. The policy relates to land and ecosystem restoration to the extent that it promotes indigenous practice of agro-forestry in Nepal. If properly implemented, it can enrich the biological diversity and environmental conservation on the one hand and ensure the food security of the marginalized peasants of Nepal, on the other hand. --- from Uprety, L. P. 2021. Land Related Policies and Laws in Nepal: A Discussion Paper. Kathmandu, Nepal: Community Self-reliance Centre (CSRC), International Land Coalition (ILC) & NES-Nepal

title: Land Cadastral Survey and Measurement Act, 1963
rows: Land Cadastral Survey and Measurement Act, 1963

One of the earliest land legislations in Nepal after the end of the 104-year oligarchic rule of the Rana family, this legislation classified land, defined the relationship between different people and land, and ensuring that the proper ownership of land. The downsides of this legislation is that it was never well implemented and was amended 8 times. The recent amendment of the act has focused more on commercialization of land and therefore has been under criticism.

title: National Wetlands Policy 2003
rows: The National Wetlands Policy defines wetlands in Nepal and its primary goal is to conserve and manage wetlands resources wisely and in a sustainable way with local peoples participation. "The major objectives of the policy is to Identify Nepals wetlands and prepare detailed management plans for each of them to prevent degradation and disappearance of wetlands with long-term conservation and development initiatives for wise use of wetlands resources by implementing the management plans on the basis of priorities, potentiality and urgency; Identify local peoples knowledge, skill and practice regarding wetlands and promote their innovations and traditional research for the sustainable use of wetlands resources; Conserve and manage wetlands according to the needs and on the basis of scientific knowledge and technology; Promote womens participation for the conservation, management and wise use of wetlands; Gradually implement international treaties for wetlands conservation; Disseminate information to raise public awareness about wetlands." -- https://leap.unep.org/countries/np/national-legislation/national-wetlands-policy-2059-2003

title: Europe's drought already threatens energy, tourism and agriculture -      ,
rows: Europe's drought already threatens energy, tourism and agriculture -      ,

Talking about drought after it rained a few days ago sounds strange at first glance. But after the driest summer in 500 years in Europe last year, much of the continent is now gripped by a winter drought. And this is raising concerns about water security for households, farmers, businesses and energy. The images of dried-up riverbeds and shrunken lakes usually associated with summer heatwaves have come this time as early as winter. Global climate trends clearly show that natural disasters will increasingly impact economies. Countries' development plans must take account of their growing direct and indirect economic consequences.     ,       ,     .   -   500       ,          .         , ,   .        ,        ,       .     ,     -     .                .

The fight covers two main activities: agrotechnics, which aim to improve the conditions under which the plant develops, and breeding, which improves it, Assoc. Prof. Encho MIANUSHEV The essence of drought is limited rainfall, dry soil, elevated temperatures, severely reduced relative humidity. It is very often accompanied by strong dry winds - arid winds. Drought is a multifaceted phenomenon. It affects the biogeochemical factors of the environment, which are very much determined by the soil and its properties. Soil participates together with plants, animals and micro-organisms, together forming the biosphere, which depends to a large extent on it. Drought is therefore a complex phenomenon and a comprehensive solution to the problems of combating it is required in order to avoid its impact. There are still a number of issues in the drought problem that are worthy of discussion and which can provide guidance and solutions for a comprehensive and programmatic fight against this dangerous phenomenon. title: Save Bulgarian Soils -
rows: At this rate, 90% of the soil could be eroded by 2050. According to a UN report, we have 60-80 harvests left. Each year the world loses 50-70 million acres (approximately 50% of Bulgaria's land area) of farmland to soil erosion. Bulgarian soils are no exception, conventional industrial farming in Bulgaria also leads to degradation and erosion of the top fertile layer of the soil. In 2018, the European Union published a report that assessed southern Europe at high risk of desertification, with a focus on the north-central and north-eastern regions of Bulgaria. Restoring soil organic matter deposition, soil structure and biological balance are directly linked to soil hydrological balance and drought resilience. title: Forests will be one of the ecosystems most affected by climate change -     -
rows: Forests will be one of the ecosystems most affected by climate change -     -

Forests are among the most important and climate-vulnerable ecosystems. They play a key role in carbon sequestration and long-term carbon storage. At the same time, climate change has the potential to cause significant, often adverse changes in forests in global and local contexts. Although the general public in Bulgaria often refuses to accept the existence of climate change, there are already examples that require more serious attention, understanding and, in some cases, action. A number of these have been outlined in various strategic documents, but their actual implementation requires a broad consensus in society, trained professionals and a willingness to invest.    -       .              .        ,          . ,             ,    ,   - ,       .        ,           ,      .

title: Experts: the largest number of forest fires in the last 15 years, in Bulgaria the situation is no different - : -      15 ,      -
rows: Experts: the largest number of forest fires in the last 15 years, in Bulgaria the situation is no different - : -      15 ,      -

Fortunately, forest fires do not always result in the destruction of all trees in the affected areas. It depends on the type of fire (top or ground), the tree species, their age, the depth of the soils, the type, depth and moisture of the dead forest cover, the presence of combustible material - dry branches, bushes, etc., said Nelly Doncheva, Head of Forests at WWF. Some tree species, such as dry-resistant oaks, for example, successfully withstand fires and most of the trees, especially the older ones with thicker bark, survive, continue to grow and seed. In this case, no further measures are needed. Studies in the Pirin Mountains have shown that ancient black and white mulberry trees have survived several fires without being significantly damaged. If the fire took place in a nature reserve - according to the legislation, no artificial afforestation is allowed in the reserves, regardless of the causes of damage to the tree vegetation, but reliance is placed on natural processes leading to reforestation.                 . title: Karst and karst natural complexes -
rows: The "karst" phenomenon is widespread in natural complexes varying according to their geographical location. Its study has a fundamental role not only for the enrichment and extension of scientific knowledge, but also for the development, planning and management of the territory, as well as for the daily life of people.             .              ,    ,     ,      .

title: Caves and karst formations -
rows: Karst in Bulgaria occupies 22.7% of the country's territory and is developed on different age, thickness and fractured carbonate rocks (limestones, dolomites and marbles). About 5100 caves have been found in Bulgaria so far. They offer a unique environment for life - specific microclimate (almost constant temperature and humidity), limited or completely absent daylight. So far 704 species of invertebrates are known to inhabit Bulgarian caves. Many of the known invertebrates inhabit only one cave and a given karst area. Such are most species of cave beetles, millipedes and woodlice. Destroying the fauna of a single cave can therefore cause entire animal species to disappear from the face of the earth forever. Karst and karst formation In the broadest sense, karst refers to a set of processes and phenomena that take place in limestone rocks subjected to the mechanical and chemical action of water and lead to the formation of characteristic landforms. Caves are temporary or permanent refuges for a range of organisms. The diversity of life in a cave is not great and the ecosystem is much more fragile than most of those on the surface. Water pollution, visitor traffic, trash, flooding, and changing air and temperature patterns all contribute to disrupting food availability and disrupting cave ecosystems. Once destroyed, there is little chance that these ecosystems will recover, and it is likely that some unique troglobiont will be gone forever.     22,7%           ,      (,   ).        5100 .       -   (    ),      .     704   ,    .            .      ,   .                       .     -          ,     ,                .         .              -,      .   ,  , , ,                     .  ,        ,          .

title: More mining companies are shutting down or operating with limited capacity -
rows: More mining companies are shutting down or operating with limited capacity -

The impact of the Covid-19 coronavirus pandemic continues to squeeze the global mining industry. In some regions, companies have already ceased operations altogether. In other regions, a partial resumption of operations is being undertaken, but with the caveat that capital spending will be reduced, Bloomberg reports. Unprecedented mine closures and supply-chain disruptions have put the outlook for industrial and precious metals at risk, while global demand remains clouded on expectations of the worst recession in almost a century. China, one of the world's biggest buyers of metals, has recorded its first economic contraction in decades.It is difficult to quantify this downturn as countries expand, revise or ease measures to contain the crisis. South Africa, one of the leading metals producers, has allowed companies to resume operations at half their usual capacity. Peru has extended a national blockade until 26 April, and the Canadian province of Quebec is prioritising metals mining to allow businesses to emerge from the crisis. Meanwhile, Zambia said it persuaded big business name Glencore Plc to reverse its decision to close its copper mines in the African country. Mining companies are also experiencing serious difficulties in terms of manpower, as they have been forced to relocate thousands of staff to comply with movement restrictions. Industry giants Rio Tinto Group and BHP Group have squeezed their capital spending because of the virus, and a growing number of industry-related companies are shutting down or reducing capacity because of the restrictions. title: Afforestation: characteristics, types, examples -  : , ,
rows: Afforestation is the process of planting trees to establish a commercial plantation of natural forest or to mitigate ecological damage. The latter is due to the process of rehabilitation or restoration of the natural area. Deforestation, on the other hand, refers to the act of planting trees where there were none originally, or deforestation. title: Bnin Code foncier et domanial
rows: The Code foncier et domanial in Benin is legislation that regulates land tenure and property rights. It establishes rules for land acquisition, ownership, and transfer, and addresses land disputes. The law recognizes customary, private, and public land, protects women's rights, and establishes a regulatory authority for land management. Its purpose is to ensure secure land tenure, equitable distribution, and sustainable land management.

title: Loi Cadre sur l'Environnement en Rpublique du Bnin
rows: Loi Cadre sur l'Environnement en Rpublique du Bnin

The "Loi Cadre sur l'Environnement en Rpublique du Bnin" of February 12, 1999 establishes a legal framework for environmental protection and management in Benin. While it does not specifically focus on land and ecosystem restoration, it promotes sustainable practices and emphasizes the conservation of natural resources, including biodiversity. The law encourages environmental education, awareness, and public participation, which indirectly support efforts related to land and ecosystem restoration.

title: DIAGNOSTIC APPROFONDI DU CADRE LEGISLATIF ET REGLEMENTAIRE DU SECTEUR FORESTIER ET PROPOSITIONS DACTIONS POUR LA MISE EN UVRE DE LA REDD+
rows: DIAGNOSTIC APPROFONDI DU CADRE LEGISLATIF ET REGLEMENTAIRE DU SECTEUR FORESTIER ET PROPOSITIONS DACTIONS POUR LA MISE EN UVRE DE LA REDD+

It is a legislative and regulatory framework of the forest sector in Benin for the implementation of REDD+. The document aims to analyze the existing legal framework, identify obstacles and necessary reforms, and propose priority actions for integrating REDD+ into policies. The expected outcomes include a diagnostic analysis, recommendations for legal changes, and an information plan involving stakeholders.

title: LOI N 034-2009/AN PORTANT REGIME FONCIER RURAL
rows: LOI N 034-2009/AN PORTANT REGIME FONCIER RURAL

Law No. 034-2009/AN in Burkina Faso establishes the land tenure system for rural areas. Its objectives include ensuring equitable access to rural lands, promoting investments and productivity in agriculture, sustainable management of natural resources, and maintaining social peace. The law defines various terms related to land tenure and outlines the national policy for securing rural land rights. The policy aims to protect property rights, promote equitable access to land, support sustainable land use, prevent conflicts, and establish an effective institutional framework. The policy is developed and updated through a participatory process involving various rural stakeholders.

title: LAW N 14/003 OF FEBRUARY 11, 2014 RELATING TO THE CONSERVATION OF NATURE
rows: LAW N 14/003 OF FEBRUARY 11, 2014 RELATING TO THE CONSERVATION OF NATURE

LAW N 14/003 OF FEBRUARY 11, 2014 RELATING TO THE CONSERVATION OF NATURE EXPLANATORY MEMORANDUM The Democratic Republic of Congo is full of important natural and biological resources. In view of the importance of these in growth, development, the fight against population poverty and climate regulation, it is essential to put in place effective strategies and rules for the conservation of these resources. Indeed, the conservation of nature is currently governed by Ordinance-Law No. 69-041 of August 22, 1969, the execution of which has proved difficult, for lack of provision for implementing measures. In addition, this ordinance-law no longer takes into account the new challenges imposed by sustainable development and the fight against poverty of local populations who do not actively participate in the management of protected areas in order to derive legitimate advantages and benefits. It is silent on the obligation to sensitize, inform and involve local populations as well as all public and private actors concerned in the process of developing and implementing national policy on conservation and sustainable use of biological diversity, as well as the practical arrangements for consulting them. After the adoption by the Democratic Republic of Congo of the national strategy document and action plan for biological diversity, as well as that of the strategy for the conservation of protected areas, it is important to provide the country with an appropriate legal framework. to the modern principles of management of biological and genetic resources, traditional knowledge and protected areas as well as to the requirements for the implementation of the international treaties and conventions that it has ratified. These include the treaty on the conservation and sustainable management of forest ecosystems in Central Africa, the convention on biological diversity, the convention on the protection of world cultural and natural heritage, the Ramsar convention on Wetlands of International Importance, of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. Such is the general scheme of this law. Law n 14/003 of February 11, 2014 relating to the conservation of nature in order to change this inactive law.

title: LAW N011/2002 OF AUGUST 29, 2002 ON FORESTRY In the Democratic Republic of Congo
rows: LAW N011/2002 OF AUGUST 29, 2002 ON FORESTRY In the Democratic Republic of Congo

The basic text of the Congolese forest regime and its implementing measures date from April 11, 1949. The implementation of this regime has proven difficult as the political, economic, social and cultural evolution of the country progresses. . Thus, we note that, 42 years after its accession to independence, the Democratic Republic of Congo has not yet adopted an appropriate forest regime, namely a legal framework that allows both the forest to fulfill its ecological and social functions in balance, to the forest administration to contribute substantially to national development and to the local populations to participate actively in the management of the forests in order to be able to derive a legitimate benefit from them. FORESTRY MANAGEMENT a. Any forest to be granted is the subject of a preliminary investigation so as to be able to make it clear and free of all rights. Here too, the consultation of the populations bordering the forest is compulsory to guarantee social peace and the peaceful enjoyment of the forests granted. b. To ensure the sustainable development of natural resources, this Act introduces two concepts into forest management, that of forest inventory and that of forest management. vs. In this law, the forest concession is clearly different from the land concession and constitutes a "sui generis" real estate right because it relates only to timber. It is underpinned by a forest concession contract accompanied by specifications in which the rights and obligations of the contracting parties are specified. The forest concession can be acquired by two ways: one main, the adjudication, and the other, exceptional, the mutual agreement. However, the local communities, that is to say in fact the local populations, can acquire, free of charge, a forest concession on their ancestral lands. d. Compared to the decree of 11 April and the law of 1949, this law inserts specific provisions relating to forest taxation into the forest regime. This differs from ordinary taxation and aims to establish a forest taxation policy that is able to guarantee both sustainable management of forest resources, an incentive for better forest management and reconciliation of development objectives. forest industry and increased forest revenues. This law, being general, is limited to defining the principles and general matters, which will be the subject of regulatory texts thus allowing the government a dynamic adaptation to the socio-economic conditions of the country.
